author: pipermerriam
content:
<@!692550965856829481> after reading through `https://hackmd.io/-_II-qyQR6OOeS8J7gMVgQ?view1` 

1) I'm not sure that the caching mechanism will be effective or sufficient to be useful for stateless clients.

I don't believe there is any global heuristic that can be used to define what should and should not be cached that would be effective across the various different "shaped" use cases.  A client might be used for any of:  backend infrastructure, personal use, developer use.  Each of these use cases is going to have different access patterns and even across the same types of use cases, the access patterns may be very different.  Because of this, I suspect that such a strategy is likely to only be useful for a constrained set of use cases and would thus be difficult to roll out new core networking infrastructure to support it.

2) Introduction of a new type of network operator (the Referrer) raises concerns for a few reasons.  It's highly unlikely that we can incentivise these nodes at the protocol level and it is reasonable to expect this network to require incentivisation.  If the assumption is that nodes will pay for access to the Referrer network, then we should probably just focus on the LES protocol because it serves the purpose of providing on-demand data and supports incentivisation payments.

For these reasons I've been focused on solutions that 1) do not depend on incentivisation **and** 2) does not create networks with asymetry in the types of nodes

author: pipermerriam
content:
Incentives based solutions seem to fall short because we likely cannot provide the incentives at the protocol level which requires the incentives to come from the consumers which limits the use cases where such a solution will help since the use cases where people are willing to pay for data access are in the extreme minority.

Asymetric network based solutions fall short because they depend on maintaining a sufficient majority of "providers" to serve the "consumers", and unless the network natively implements swarming behavior to allow a large imbalance between "providers" and "consumers".  Similarly, just like in bittorrent, it seems necessary to ensure that the distinction between "provider" and "consumer" is thin and that "consumers" can easily also be "providers".

author: pipermerriam
content:
Yes, there are examples of people being willing to pay for services that provide value.  There are also a lot of examples of people being unwilling to pay for services that provide value (news? social media? weather?).  Specifically, I don't think there are many examples of people being broadly willing to pay for data.  Wikipedia? Research Journals/Publications? Pirating Movies/Music? Most of the internet....  

I'm skeptical that people will be willing to pay for such a service and I'm additionally skeptical that the subset that would be willing to pay would choose to do so, over the cost of just running a full node.  My thinking here is that if you're willing to pay, it is because you need high quality reliable service, and under this model, the more reliable way to do that is just to run your own full node.

 I think the topic of state provision is still at ‚Äúinfrastructure‚Äù level,  therefore people are likely to be willing to pay, and if they aren‚Äôt but value it enough,  they can still get access to it by running their own node (as you mentioned) and potentially paying with exchange of services. So my follow up question is: why is it a problem if people decide to run their own nodes?
